passages.text: EUROPE | Building, Construction & Housebuilders
Question Bank for Building Products & Materials at Jefferies Industrials Conf

The Jefferies Industrials Conference on Sep 3rd and 4th will feature 5 companies under our direct coverage and 20 corporates operating across the Building and Construction space (Build Materials, Build Products, Infrastructure, Distributors & Homebuilders). To help with prep for these meetings (or any others you may have through this conference season) in this report we provide question lists for the companies attending that are under our coverage.

Strategy. Mgmt has just made a very significant investment in the company. Is the mgmt LTIP now set, and if so what are management incentivized on? What will mgmt view as a success in terms of the split from Holcim - is there a valuation being targeted, a market cap size, a ROCE? What is the feedback on the product mix - what are the synergies between materials and envelope?

Consensus appears short of the medium term targeted revenue growth of \(5 - 8\%\) . How does mgmt view this target near term while domestic markets may be weaker - will the company look to use M&A to bridge the gap? How should we think about the balance sheet - if deals in one year are slim, with the greater balance sheet capacity be rolled into the following years M&A or will mgmt look at buybacks each year as the balancing factor to keep the balance sheet efficient? When will the company ask for approval for buybacks?

Index. What is the update on country of domicile from S&P & Russell? What about the Swiss indexes? What is the background behind the heavy Swiss influence (listing, incorporation, HQ etc) and when can that change?

M&A. Mgmt targets \(2 - 3\%\) sales growth pa from M&A, with a focus on \(10+\) bolt- on deals per year. What size does this encapsulate, how does the pipeline look? Sellside seem to think mgmt want to do a big deal - how does mgmt evaluate transformation deals? What product areas are priority for Amrize - aggregates, building envelope? Is there scope for anything more in cement - if so where? On building envelope, what product areas are high priority and what type of synergies will be targeted?

Trading. Can you talk through current trading conditions - USA, Canada. Management have talked about the potential for a \(10\%\) bounce in volumes once a 'framework for trade is in place' - what are the drivers and catalysts for that? Rockwool reported in the last few weeks a significant deterioration in non- resi in USA reflecting projects delays - is Amrize seeing similar? Downside in FY25 guidance at the 1H25 results was largely driven by higher corporate costs? What measures have been put in place to try to reduce the impact of these - can Amrize go above and beyond the \(\) 250m\$ savings targeted? At the 1H25 the net debt at \(\) 5.6bn\(was meaningfully higher than consensus? What can be done on working capital in 2H25 (\) \ \(2bn?\) . Does guidance for FY25 net debt EBITDA of 1.5x include an amount for M&A?

Building Envelope. What is the breakdown of Amrize's commercial roofing exposure to the re- roof cycle, regular repair & maintenance and new build? What end markets are key for Amrize - restaurants, offices, retail, manufacturing, data centres? What is the view on Kingspan's intended entry into commercial roofing and evaluation of entering the resi roofing/shingle market too? What more can be done on margins in this business? What are the drivers - operational leverage? What is the margin potential of this business?

Building Materials. The group is sold- out in most of its cement plants and global imports are not part of its cement strategy. So what more can be done to increase volumes in USA and Canada? What is the strategy around mineralization and when could it start to influence? How concentrated are procs in cement around the St Genevieve plant? How does Amrize's aggregate businesses compare to the top 5 in the USA - resources look much lower than the peers - is this something that is being looked at? How does Amrize get margins up in aggregates towards the leaders in the market? Ready mix has minimal vertical integration - why does it stay part of the portfolio?
Amrize (AMRZ US)RatingHoldPrice52.0Price target, $49.4Market Cap, $ m27,527Free float100%
ManagementCEO &amp; ChairmanJan Philipp JenischCFOIan Johnston

CEO transition - What will Jim (Mintern CEO) do differently from Albert Manifold (previous CEO)? When Albert came into the position it was all about transition - what will Jim's focus be? Nancy brings expertise from outside the industry - what does she think she can bring that might be different?

Investor day. What to expect at investor day at end of Sep? What feedback has been received from investors about what they want to understand better at the group? Will the company release some long term targets, updates on trading or guidance for FY26?

Portfolio change. History shows there are no sacred cows in the CRH portfolio - how should we think about disposals from here? What is the scale of opportunity for growth capex in terms of investment by product area, and what top line growth can it bring? What are the priorities for M&A by product and location? What does M&A pipeline look like - are there more larger deals in the pipeline or bolt ons? How does Nancy see the deployment of capital by region? How should we think about capital allocation - if leverage continues to be below 1.5x net debt EBITDA, will the share buyback pick up?

Portfolio positioning. Has the group taken market share in roadbuilding, and how does this business unit influence margin in the downstream, and the cyclicality of the portfolio? How much push back are you still seeing on the benefits of vertical integration within the portfolio? Is the vertical integration to Outdoor Living sufficient to mean this business cannot be separated out? Why isn't Infra Solutions managed with Materials? The balance of N America vs International - what is mgmt's desired level? What are the synergies of having this more global approach?

Near term trading. How does CRH see the key drivers and end markets in 2025 and 2026? Price and volume by product? End market dynamics? There are lots of discussions on the scale and time frame for the remaining IIJA funding - how does this play out through to 2027? What is the near term outlook for state spending on infra? What are the group hearing on the new Infra Bill currently being discussed? There is a very mixed picture on US non- resi - what is CRH seeing? New build resi - any signs of pickup? Resi R&R is forecast to go back to growth in 2025 (NAHB) - what is CRH seeing in outdoor living? How does Canada volumes, price and margin differ from US? European recovery - Central and Eastern Europe recovery appears to be stalling a touch, what is CRH seeing? What leverage does the group have to leverage to any Ukraine rebuild, German infra programme, UK resi new build. How is Australia progressing?
Medium term: How far can the vertically integrated model take margins and ROCE? European decarbonization - what can it do to margins in Europe and how is CRH positioned for this?
Index - what is S&P telling CRH on S&P500 inclusion?
CRH (CRH US, CRH LN)RatingRestrictedPrice114.3Price target, $RestrictedPrice target, pRestrictedMarket Cap, $ m78,081Free float100%
ManagementCEOJim MinternCFONancy BueseChairmanRichie Boucher
2Q25: Feedback From Call, 7 August 2025First View: 2Q25 Results, 7 August 2025Updated View of Potential Index Changes, 5 March 2025

Recognition of value. Can you discuss the benefits of staying global rather than separating your business as a couple of peers have done? Mgmt talk of a range of options to recognize value of the USA assets - what are these?

Capital allocation. To 2025- 30 Heidelberg targets €5- 6bn into both ones, €5- 6bn back to shareholders, which it says leaves €10bn potential excess capital. Last few years M&A was focused on recycling and circular economy in Europe, heavyside in the US, selective deals elsewhere (cement Tanzania, Indonesia). What is the priority for FY25- 30- - regionally (US?), products (aggregates, more recycling?)? What about further vertical integration - asphalt? Ready mix? Concrete products? Would the company consider breaching the top end of its net debt/ EBITDA target for a big deal? What kind of financial metrics would a deal be judged on? What kind of synergies could be captured - logistics, operating best practice, local pricing? How should we think about the 'excess capital' that is referenced - is this for a big deal or more likely back to shareholders? Will the use of this only be considered at the end of the period or on an annual basis? How does the board think about buybacks, is there scope to increase the annual rate - is that why the family sold a part of their stake? Disposals - are they still a focus? What can we expect to come - India? Parts of Africa?

Trading. FY25 guidance of €3.25- 3.55bn - what level of organic growth does this reflect (ie ex FX and structure)? Europe - is it flat or growing? What stimulus in Europe is making a difference? UK, E Europe, Scandi - what are the trends? Any ideas what German infra programme will look like or when we will hear more? Heidelberg is closing capacity in Germany and there is the constraint of carbon credits - how will they supply into a volume upturn? USA - soft start to the year, is July/ Aug any better? What is the update on pricing in US cement, aggregates? What is confidence of price offsetting costs? Australia and Indonesia are the largest exposures in Southern Hemisphere. Australia has seen significant consolidation - is this impacting market behaviour? Indonesia has struggled with price over costs, similar for India. How are these markets performing? Africa saw a really strong 2Q25 (especially Ghana) - what is the outlook for this region?

Costs. Carbon costs are down in 2025, but what about energy costs in 2025? What about other costs such as wage inflation - how do they offset? The group's €500m Transformation Accelerator cost saving programme (6- 7% of group fixed costs and mostly in Europe) - what does this actually involve? How much will be retained? What difference can this make to margins? Heidelberg has announced another 13- 17% of capacity closure to 2030 (bringing total closures to 30%) but is there scope for more/less and what about others in the industry?

Impact of carbon costs. How will the change in the benchmark for carbon credit (CC) allocation drive pricing in 2026? What level of CC does Heidelberg have in inventory - what is the outlook for CC costs per year for Heidelberg by 2027? Heidelberg's lower carbon product range, Evobuild, is targeted to reach 50% of sales by 2030. How will this be achieved - what are the practical constraints, workability of product, issues of customer acceptance etc. What is the pricing strategy for lower carbon products (significant price premium or lower price to try to convert more production)? How do these products change cost of goods (less cement should make them cheaper, but cost of gathering recycled product)? What legislation is there to drive the uptake of these lower carbon/zero carbon products? The target on EvoZero (limited carbon cement created through carbon capture and storage) is for 2 plants to be delivering by 2030 (Norway, UK). What of the other facilities (they have plans in Sweden, Belgium, 2 in Germany, Bulgaria, Czechia? Morocco, Canada, USA)? What about the \(\) 500m$ funding from US govt - will the CCUS in Mitchell happen? Where are you with the opex costs for all your CCUS? At what carbon price are they profitable? Is it practical to have it in each country they operate in? How should we think about green capex in the longer term?
Heidelberg Materials (HEI GR)RatingBuyPrice204.9Price target, €236.5Market Cap, € m36,244Free float72%

Strategy. How should we think about Holcim's targets for 'above- market' revenue growth of \(3 - 5\%\) on average pa (with \(1 - 2\%\) from bolt- ons), and \(6 - 10\%\) growth pa in recurring EBIT - given potential pricing in Europe this appears quite conservative. Holcim targets to achieve a sales split of 50:50 between Building Materials (BM: cement and aggregates) and Building Solutions (BS: high value concrete, energy efficient building products), from the current 63:37 ratio - but why does the company see the need to have this mix of business - what does the combination bring? How has the shareholder base changed since the spin of Amrize? How have the questions and perception of the company changed since that time?

Decarbonisation. How should we think about the group's decarbonization strategy driving the business? Can it drive additional volumes from market share gains? What changes to regulation, build practices are required for this? What about pricing power - what premiums are being achieved - how long can these last? What about the ability to lower costs - lower fuel costs, lower raw material costs? How can this be done, on what kind of timescale and what kind of investment is required? What about the outlook for carbon capture usage and storage (CCUS) - what are the economics of production - at what carbon price is it economic? What level of subsidies/grants are required to make sufficient IRR? What proportion of cement sold in 2030 or 2035 could be nearzero carbon if all of Holcim's plants come on stream to schedule and capacity?

Europe. Holcim already has some of the strongest profitability amongst its peers in Europe. Why is this - size, access to raw materials, newness of facilities, network? What is the scope for upside, and how will Holcim get there - operational leverage, lower carbon offering driving pricing, lower carbon offering driving lower costs, operational efficiency? What are you seeing across individual markets in terms of signs of recovery? How should we think about costs of carbon and changes in carbon credit allocation benchmark, impacting pricing for 2026? What restructuring can be seen across European cement so far in reaction to this cost of carbon - capacity closures, asset sales? What is Holcim's potential leverage to the medium term themes of German infra, Ukraine rebuild? Any ideas what German infra programme will look like or when we will hear more? How will this potential step up in demand be accommodated given carbon credit allocations?

Latin America. What drives the very high margins in this business - is it bagged vs bulk mix, vertical integration down to owned distribution, market positions locally? What drives upside/downside from here - acquisitions, greater breadth of products in distribution, operational leverage from expansion of distribution branches, move back to bagged from bulk in Mexico as infra tails off, lower costs from greater recycling? What is the outlook by country - Mexico is the largest (11% of group, 50% of division) and Ecuador (4% of group). What do we need to watch for in terms of FCF conversion in the region? Anything political to watch for including anything that might impact repatriation?

AMEA. AMEA is the least concentrated division of the group (16 countries) - are disposals realistic? The Nigeria sales looks back on but at a lower price - will there be some assets left at Holcim? Australia has seen significant consolidation - are there other products which can be added here? How should we think about that impacting the competitive dynamics and margin potential in Australia? Algeria and Morocco (and increasingly Egypt) have an export strategy - how does the Amrize spin and the US tariffs impact this?

M&A. The group targets regular bolt- ons and the group's revenue targets reflect \(1 - 2\%\) growth pa for this. How does the pipeline look in terms of scale in total, scale of deals at an individual level? The group targets \(50\%\) of revenues from Building Solutions, does this require a more transformational deal (CHF4- 6bn could be financed by internal cash flow by 2028)? This focus on Building Envelope product groups segment (insulation, roofing, walls) how does the company capture synergies? How will these acquisitions impact the group's profile of margins and free cash flow conversion?
Holcim (HOLN SW)RatingBuyPrice66.6Price target, CHF79.3Market Cap, CHF m37,762Free float91%

Sika (Buy, PT CHF274)Organic sales growth – Talk through why you consistently outperform underlying construction markets in most years. • What is the penetration rate of key products in key regions? • Do you believe the mega- trends (urbanisation, climate change & sustainability, demographic change) you often talk about are becoming increasing tailwinds and could actually increase the scale of organic outperformance in coming years? • Americas - talk through the timeline of upside you expect to see from various government initiatives (e.g. Biden's IIJA, Trump's tariffs aimed to drive onshoring) and risks to this materialising? What is your view on the more macro- driven part of your business (e.g. offices, retail, etc) which is not supported by government initiatives? • EMEA – how sustainable do you see the improving volume trend and can you give us some colour by region? • Asia/ Pacific – what drove the further step- down into 2Q25 and when do you foresee the whole division moving back to flat or positive YoY? Is there much difference in trends between Chinese direct versus distribution, primary versus secondary cities etc? Talk through the pricing dynamic in China. • What are your latest assumptions for global auto production and Sika's ability to reach its historical 7- 10% outperformance? • What are the drivers of the mid- term 6- 9% pa local currency growth target? • Can you give us a sense of how the integration of Global into the regional divisions and moving around of divisional heads has impacted operations on the ground? • There is a lot of discussion about how competition is evolving in your market, especially with other listed players making moves into construction chemicals/ US roofing - what are your views here? • Criven, the private equity company, bought the divested assets from the MBCC deal – what sort of competitor have they been so far?

Margin potential - On an underlying basis (i.e. excluding one- offs), it seems like the EBIT margin will be relatively flat this year despite mild volume growth – why is this, and what are the implications of this moving forward? • What needs to happen for you to reach your mid- term EBITDA margin target of 20- 23% from 2026 onwards? • Pricing – you have suggested that maybe you would have taken a different approach to dealing with the rampant cost inflation of 2021- 22; how so? • One of the things investors like about Sika is that even through periods of cost inflation and margin squeeze, prices do not typically fall again when cost deflation kicks in – is this still a valid way to look at the business, or does the difficult demand backdrop/ possible step- up in competition impact this? • What is your view on sequential raw material and pricing movements in 2025- 26? • Are there any pockets where you are seeing pressure to cut pricing? • Remind us of the time lag with which you typically pass cost inflation through in pricing? • Why has the target for operational efficiency (i.e. 50bps improvement pa) been dropped? • Would you forgo your mid- term margin target for a larger scale M&A deal?

MBCC & other M&A - You recently increased the synergy target from MBCC by CHF20m pa in 2025 and 2026. What was behind this and how much further could this go? How far ahead of schedule are you already in 1H25 versus the original synergy schedule? • There has been a lot of discussion about the relative cultures of Sika and MBCC, and how compatible they might be – what are your thoughts on this, and are there any elements of Sika's "culture" you have introduced into MBCC? • What are your learnings for larger deals going forward, or might MBCC make you reconsider doing larger deals entirely? • What sort of product areas and regions are you looking to gain exposure to through M&A, and of what size (i.e. sales pa)? • Why would M&A be preferred over organic growth for these? • Possible timeline for the next big deal?

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
